results.title: Binning street
results.creator_credit: Gillian Coote and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Changing Australia”.
Looks at the range of people, culture, attitudes, traditions and the history that dwells in Binning Street, Erskineville. The program investigates current family life in Australian society in the 1980’s and how it has changed.

results.title: Catch them as they go: religious change in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cross and Argosy Films for Network 0\28
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Changing Australia”.
Looks at young people who, dissatisfied with life have turned to religions such as Hare Krishna, Muslim and the Charismatic Pentecostal Movement.

results.title: Up for grabs
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Changing Australia”.
The 1980’s were a time of great change in the Aboriginal struggle for land rights. This film documents the passing of legislation in the N.S.W. Parliament which took control from the Aboriginal Lands Commission and passed it to local Aboriginal Land Councils. The Act was opposed by many Aboriginal activists, including Paul Coe and The Munros, father and son, but supported by others, such as Pat O’Shane. Focusing on the town of Moree where the Munros live, the program depicts the history of the Aborigines’ dispossession and their struggle to regain their lands or be compensated for their loss.

results.title: The Awakening bell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Amongst the Vietnamese community in Australia there are often unresolved tensions between those who left Vietnam before 1975 and the boat people who left after 1975. In 1987 Buddhist priest and Nobel Peace Prize nominee, Thich Nhat Hanh, accompanied by his co-worker, Cao Ngoc Phuong, a Buddhist nun, visited Australia in an attempt to reconcile some of those differences and to teach those who suffered how to free themselves from painful memories. This moving documentary, focuses on this impressive pair and their philosophy which teaches that one must have peace within oneself in order to achieve peace in the world, so that meditation becomes a drastic peace action.

results.title: Mountains of change
results.creator_credit: Peter Hicks, Peter Beilby and Entertainment Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Using archival footage, interviews and dramatic reconstruction, this program presents a comprehensive history of skiing in Australia from its beginnings last century to the booming tourist industry it has become today.

results.title: G'day: new accents in australian tourism
results.creator_credit: Colin South, Anne Basser and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Tourism is Australia’s largest employer and continues to grow in importance. This program looks at the importance of understanding the cultures our visitors come from and also at the importance of developing foreign language skills for those involved in the tourist industry. We see examples of how Australia can capitalise on the language and cultural skills which already exist within the migrant communities. The program also considers alternative types of tourism, some of which are beginning to involve Aborigines on a more active basis.

results.title: Family life
results.creator_credit: Tony Chenn, Ugo Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Fairfield in Sydney is a community of diverse ethnic groups. This program looks at families from three of these groups - Aborigine, Italo-Australian and Anglo-Saxon/Kampuchean. Each family is observed as they discuss how they cope and intend to cope with the cultural differences which surround them.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Chenn, Ugo Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

group_siblings.title: You jump, you fly: a multicultural textile project linking health and art
group_siblings.creator_credit: Luigi Acquisto, Australia Council and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: You jump, you fly: a multicultural textile project linking health and art
results.creator_credit: Luigi Acquisto, Australia Council and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
At the Coburg Community Health Centre, Anne Marie Power, textile artist, talks about groups of women that were linked together through a textile project. The common theme revolved around their houses and lives, and the women were able to develop skills which had previously been undervalued. The aim was to increase the self-awareness and self-esteem of the participants thus resulting in better health. The women with well-developed skills taught the others so a sense of group was developed.
results.title_for_label: You jump, you fly: a multicultural textile project linking health and art
results.creator_credit_for_label: Luigi Acquisto, Australia Council and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
